title: Improve SP Documentation (VISION & ARCHITECTURE)
description:
**Requirements:**
- Complete all TODOs in VISION.md and ARCHITECTURE.md
- Improve documentation clarity and standards compliance
- Add concrete use case examples
- Define SP specification more clearly

**Design Decisions:**
- Follow claude/documentation-standards.md throughout
- Maintain consistency across all documentation

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All TODOs in VISION.md and ARCHITECTURE.md are resolved
- Documents comply with documentation-standards.md
- Clear examples illustrate key concepts
- SP specification is unambiguous

title: Follow Documentation Standards in VISION.md & ARCHITECTURE.md
description:
**Requirements:**
- Review claude/documentation-standards.md
- Apply standard formatting to VISION.md and ARCHITECTURE.md
- Ensure consistent terminology throughout both documents

**Design Decisions:**
- Follow existing documentation-standards.md patterns
- Maintain current document structure while improving clarity

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Both documents pass documentation standards checklist
- Terminology is consistent across both files
- No formatting violations remain

title: Add Use Case Examples to VISION.md
description:
**Requirements:**
- Add concrete examples of use cases that need the messaging substrate
- Show how SP solves problems that existing solutions don't address well
- Include examples of different coordination patterns in real agent systems

**Design Decisions:**
- Examples should be realistic and relatable to agent coordination
- Use consistent formatting for all examples
- Keep examples concise but complete

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- At least 3 concrete use cases documented
- Each use case shows the problem and how SP addresses it
- Examples cover different protocol patterns (REQ/REP, PUB/SUB, etc.)

title: Define SP Specification More Clearly
description:
**Requirements:**
- Define what SP is: pure Go implementation of Scalability Protocols spec
- Document which protocols SP implements (REQ/REP, PUB/SUB, PIPELINE, SURVEY, BUS, PAIR)
- Add SP history/context (evolution from Scalability Protocols spec)
- Clarify wire-protocol compatibility model

**Design Decisions:**
- Position SP clearly relative to nanomsg/nng
- Be explicit about compatibility guarantees
- Use precise technical terminology

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- SP's identity and purpose are unambiguous
- All supported protocols are listed
- Wire-protocol compatibility is clearly documented
- Reader understands SP's relationship to Scalability Protocols spec

title: Enhance ARCHITECTURE.md Documentation
description:
**Requirements:**
- Review and improve clarity of component descriptions
- Verify all design decisions are well-explained
- Check that diagrams and text align
- Validate that all sections are complete

**Design Decisions:**
- Follow documentation-standards.md structure
- Ensure architecture documentation matches actual design intent
- Keep technical accuracy as priority

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All component descriptions are clear and complete
- Design decisions have rationale explained
- Diagrams accurately represent the architecture
- No ambiguous or incomplete sections remain

title: Create Product Requirements Documents (PRDs)
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design and propose PRDs for key SP subsystems
- Cover transport layer, protocol engine, I/O workers, socket API, and testing
- Each PRD should guide implementation and testing

**Design Decisions:**
- PRDs follow standard format with Requirements, Design Decisions, Acceptance Criteria
- Focus on design clarity before implementation
- Address open questions explicitly

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All key subsystems have PRDs
- PRDs are detailed enough to guide implementation
- Open design questions are resolved or explicitly deferred

title: PRD: Transport Abstraction Layer Design
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design transport abstraction supporting Unix domain sockets and raw IP sockets
- Document interface that transport implementations must satisfy
- Define test suite for transport compatibility
- Specify performance requirements and benchmarks

**Design Decisions:**
- How the abstraction hides transport-specific details
- Interface for dial/listen/send/recv operations
- How message boundaries are preserved
- Backpressure and flow control mechanisms

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Transport interface is fully specified
- Test compatibility suite is defined
- Performance benchmarks are documented
- Design supports both Unix sockets and raw IP

title: PRD: REQ/REP Protocol Engine Design (Phase 1)
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design protocol engine for REQ/REP pattern (Phase 1 focus)
- Document REQ/REP state machine in detail
- Define how protocol engine interacts with I/O workers
- Specify message routing and request/reply matching

**Design Decisions:**
- Goroutine topology for REQ/REP engine
- Request ID generation and tracking mechanism
- Reply routing back to correct requester
- Timeout handling for unanswered requests
- Error propagation from I/O layer

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- REQ/REP state machine is fully documented
- Request tracking mechanism is specified
- Goroutine topology is clearly defined
- Interaction with I/O layer is unambiguous
- Timeout and error handling documented

title: PRD: I/O Worker and Syscall Handling Design
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/io-workers.md. Covers RecvWorker (continuous read loop), SendWorker (channel-driven writes with drain), WorkerPair (unified lifecycle), backpressure via channel fullness, and error handling strategies.

title: PRD: Socket API and Blocking Interface Design
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design public Socket API for applications
- Document synchronous Send/Recv blocking interface
- Specify socket lifecycle (Open, Close, Listen, Dial, Connect)
- Define error handling and timeout semantics

**Design Decisions:**
- Blocking semantics of Send (write-ready, sent, confirmed?)
- Behavior when Recv has no messages
- Peer address handling for datagram patterns
- Context/cancellation model

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Socket API is fully specified
- Blocking behavior is unambiguous
- Lifecycle operations are documented
- Error and timeout handling is clear

title: PRD: Testing Strategy and Quality Assurance
description:
**Requirements:**
- Define comprehensive testing strategy for SP
- Specify unit tests, integration tests, and benchmark tests
- Document wire-protocol compatibility testing
- Define performance benchmarks and targets

**Design Decisions:**
- How to test each protocol pattern
- Edge case scenarios to cover
- Wire-protocol compatibility verification method
- Performance baselines and targets
- Goroutine cleanup and leak detection tests

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Testing strategy covers all protocol patterns
- Wire-protocol compatibility tests are defined
- Performance benchmarks have specific targets
- Edge cases and error conditions are covered

title: PRD: Go-Native Async API Design (Phase 2)
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design async API leveraging Go channels and contexts
- Document how channels integrate with protocol patterns
- Specify cancellation and timeout handling with contexts
- Define relationship between sync and async APIs

**Design Decisions:**
- How channels map to protocol patterns
- Buffering strategy for receive channels
- Context cancellation propagation
- Whether applications can mix sync/async on same socket
- Migration path from sync to async

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Async API is fully specified
- Channel semantics are clear for each protocol
- Context integration is documented
- Sync/async relationship is defined
- Migration guidance is provided

title: PRD: Shared Infrastructure Design
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/shared-infrastructure.md. Covers Message Buffer Pool (sync.Pool-based with stats), Peer Registry (RWMutex, dual-indexed by ID and address), Connection Registry (maps transports to sockets), and Message type with buffer lifecycle.

title: PRD: Additional Protocol Patterns Design (Phase 2)
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design protocol engines for PUB/SUB, PIPELINE, SURVEY, BUS, and PAIR patterns
- Document state machine for each pattern
- Specify pattern-specific semantics and behaviors
- Define common protocol engine abstractions shared across patterns

**Design Decisions:**
- PUB/SUB: Subscription model, topic matching, fan-out strategy
- PIPELINE: Load balancing algorithm, worker fairness
- SURVEY: Response collection, timeout handling, partial results
- BUS: Peer discovery, message distribution
- PAIR: Connection exclusivity, buffering strategy
- Common base abstractions vs pattern-specific implementations

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All five patterns have documented state machines
- Pattern-specific semantics are clear
- Common abstractions are identified and specified
- Each pattern's goroutine topology is defined
- Differences from REQ/REP are explicitly noted
